document_metadata.description: A knowledge assembly of biological entities associated with the adaptive immune system and its relation to epilepsy.
document_metadata.name: Epilepsy - Adaptive Immune System

links.evidence: Studies have demonstrated that the membrane attack complex (MAC) of complement can evoke seizures when injected directly into rodent brain. In the course of studies that examine the role of complement in the development of experimental cerebral malaria (ECM), we observed fewer seizures in mice deficient in C5, a component required for MAC formation
Thus, C5b-C9 expression could contribute to the persistent activation of microglial cells, observed within the sclerotic hippocampus of TLE patients.

Expression of components of the complement cascade, IL-1beta, and MCP1 was prominent in FCD II cases. DISCUSSION: Our findings indicate a prominent activation of both innate and adaptive immunity, with involvement of different inflammatory pathways in FCD II cases, supporting the possible involvement of inflammation in the epileptogenesis of these lesions

We investigated the involvement of the complement cascade during epileptogenesis in a rat model of temporal lobe epilepsy (TLE), and in the chronic epileptic phase in both experimental as well as human TLE. The persistence of complement activation could contribute to a sustained inflammatory response and could destabilize neuronal networks involved.

Temporal lobe epilepsy (TLE) represents a severe and common epilepsy syndrome in patients with medically intractable epilepsy. The epileptogenic focus involves often the hippocampal formation,

The major histopathological features of HS include selective neuronal cell loss, gliosis and synaptic reorganization of the mossy fibers (mossy fiber sprouting) (Wieser and Epilepsy, 2004). However, an increasing number of evidence shows that the immune response plays a prominent role in the affected brain tissue in TLE

The major histopathological features of HS include selective neuronal cell loss, gliosis and synaptic reorganization of the mossy fibers (mossy fiber sprouting) (Wieser and Epilepsy, 2004). However, an increasing number of evidence shows that the immune response plays a prominent role in the affected brain tissue in TLE
The classical pattern of HS was observed in 8 cases with neuronal loss predominantly in CA1 and hilar regions and with sparing of the CA2 region
HLA-DR staining showed the presence of activated microglia in HS cases
C1q and C3 gene products were significantly upregulated in patient material
C1q and C3 gene products were significantly upregulated in patient material
The expression of CD59, a complement inhibitor at the level of the MAC, was increased in cells of the microglial/macrophage lineage present within the sclerotic hippocampus

In our previous microarray study in the rat we detected changes in the expression of several components of the classical pathway (C1q and C4), of the alternative pathway (Cfh) and of the common pathway (C3, C3ar1)

Interestingly, sequential infusion of individual proteins of the membrane attack pathway (C5b6, C7, C8, and C9) into the hippocampus of awake, freely moving rats induces both behavioral and electrographic seizures as well as cytotoxicity (Xiong et al., 2003), suggesting a role for the complement system in epileptogenesis.

Interestingly, sequential infusion of individual proteins of the membrane attack pathway (C5b6, C7, C8, and C9) into the hippocampus of awake, freely moving rats induces both behavioral and electrographic seizures as well as cytotoxicity (Xiong et al., 2003), suggesting a role for the complement system in epileptogenesis.
